The conversion of methyl mercaptan was examined over zeolites with MFI, FAU, BEA, MOR, CHA and MWW topology and Si/Al ratio between 10 and 19. At 450 °C, over all catalysts, the reagent has been primarily consumed into hydrocarbons and H2S. The crucial variables affecting the hydrocarbon distribution over zeolites were mainly their pore size/architecture and the amount of the acid sites. Over 3D H-ZSM-5, H-β and H-MOR zeolite, many aromatics and only few olefins were produced. In contrast, and analogous to methanol-to-hydrocarbons process, H-SSZ-13 and H-MCM-22 zeolite (containing cages and small pores) mainly produced C2-C3 olefins. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methyl mercaptan Zeolites Heterogeneous catalysis Hydrocarbons Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Methyl mercaptan is a common contaminant in natural and industrial gases. The current technologies used for removing this toxic and corrosive compound require specific solvents or include reactions using additional reagents such as H2, O2, olefins, NaOH, etc. [1,2]. Because these processes often generate waste, research efforts have been undertaken to develop alternative routes that do not need additional reagents. Among these, the catalytic conversion of methyl mercaptan into hydrocarbons and H2S (CH3SH → Hydrocarbons + H2S) is considered one of the most promising and environmentally friendly technologies. H2S produced in this reaction can be recovered by absorption in amines, and then it can be converted into elemental sulfur using the Claus process. Before 2010, only few data and discussion concerning this topic could be found in the open literature [3-5]. Accordingly, catalysts like ZSM-5 or WO3/Al2O3 were able to catalyse the methyl mercaptan conversion into dimethyl sulfide, methane and H2S as main products. Systematic studies on the catalytic conversion of CH3SH have been realized by the Montpellier group [6-8]. The authors showed that over zeolites CH3SH can be selectively converted into H2S and hydrocarbons. This process was called M2TH (for Methyl Mercaptan To Hydrocarbons). At temperatures higher than 500 °C the reaction products were methane, ethane, propane (C1-C3), and small amount of aromatics (benzene, toluene and xylene). To improve the catalyst activity and the stability against the coking, some research groups added metals and oxides to zeolites [9]. In a series of studies, Luo and collab. [10-15] examined the decomposition of CH3SH in the presence of HZSM-5 modified with rare earth metals (La, Ce, Pr, Sm, Nd, Y, Er). Methane and H2S were the major reaction products, besides small amount of C2H4 and C2H6. The same research group used Na- and Cr-modified HZSM-5 catalysts for the CH3SH degradation [16,17]. Both catalysts were more active and stable than the parent HZSM-5. The studies cited above were regularly performed at temperatures higher than 500 °C and the methyl mercaptan was transformed into H2S and a mixture of unsaturated C1-C3 hydrocarbons. Some recent publications showed that at moderate temperatures, over specific zeolite catalysts, CH3SH can be selectively converted into light olefins, which are molecules with high added value. Yu et al. [18] reported about an original methanethiol-to-olefins process, similar to the well-known methanol-to-olefins process. Accordingly, in the temperature range of 400–450 °C, CH3SH can be converted to ethylene and propylene over SSZ-13, a zeolite with CHA topology. Yields up to 50% in olefins have been obtained during the first 2 h on stream. High selectivities to light olefins, especially to ethylene, have been reported by Watanabe et al. [19] in the methanethiol-to-olefins process catalyzed by Ga-ZSM-5. This performance has been related to the low strength of the acidic sites generated by the Ga species. The aim of our contribution was to gather more knowledge on methanethiol-to-hydrocarbon process, and particularly to understand the role of the catalyst. Thus, we studied for the first time the catalytic conversion of methyl mercaptan at moderate temperatures by comparing zeolites with variable topology. Zeolites used in this study were chosen among the most used catalysts in the industrial technologies. Thus, protonic zeolites with different pore systems, including H-ZSM-5 (MFI), H-Y (FAU), H-β (BEA), H-Mordenite (MOR), H-MCM-22 (MWW) and H-SSZ-13 (CHA) were selected for this work. ZSM-5 is characterized by a 3D channel architecture and 10-membered ring (MR) pores (0.53 × 0.56 nm). Y porosity consists in large cages (1.2 nm) which are interconnected by windows of 0.74 nm. β is a 3D zeolite, with pores of 12 MR (0.66 × 0.67; 0.56 × 0.56 nm). The pore system of mordenite consists of 12 MR main channels of 0.65 × 0.7 nm, which are connected by 8 MR pores of 0.26 × 0.57 nm. MCM-22 has a 2D pore network of sinusoidal channels (0.4 × 0.55 nm) and cages (0.7 × 0.7 × 1.87 nm) which are accessible through 10 MR apertures (0.41 × 0.51 nm). Additionally, pockets of 0.71 nm in diameter and 0.70 nm in height are placed on the external surface. H-SSZ-13 consists of a 3D network possessing ellipsoidal cages (0.67 × 1.1 nm) interconnected by 8 MR micropores (0.38 × 0.38 nm). The conversion of methyl mercaptan over zeolites is carried out in a fixed bed-flow reactor, at atmospheric pressure. The work focuses on the activity and particularly to product distribution of each catalyst. The performances of zeolites will be mainly related to their topology. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts Zeolites ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 15), Faujasite Y (Si/Al = 15), Mordenite (Si/Al = 10) and β (Si/Al = 12.5) were purchased from Zeolyst International. SSZ-13 zeolite (Si/Al = 12) was provided by TotalEnergies. H-MCM-22 (Si/Al = 19) was synthesized by a hydrothermal method [20] using hexamethyleneimine (HMI, template), Aerosil 200 V fumed silica (Si source) and alkaline aqueous solution of sodium aluminate (Al source). The gel molar composition was Na 0.133/HMI 0.500/Al 0.050/Si/H2O 45. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The crystallinity of the catalysts was examined by X-ray diffraction, in the ranges 2θ = 4–50° with an angular step size of 0.0197° and an acquisition time of 0.2 s (Bruker D8 Advance device with a Bragg-Brentano configuration, Bruker Lynx Eye detector, Cu Kα radiation). Nitrogen physisorption measurements were carried out at -196 °C on a Micromeritics Tristar sorptomer, using samples outgassed under vacuum at 250 °C for 6 h. The specific surface area was determined using the BET technique. The micropore area and volume and the external surface area were determined using the t-plot method. The thermal gravimetric-mass spectrometry analysis (TGA-MS) were performed on a STA 449 F1 Jupiter instrument coupled to a mass spectrometer QMS 403 Aëolos Quadro. 10 mg of spent catalyst were heated from 40 to 900 °C at 10 °C min-1 in an air flow (30 mL min-1). The acidity of the H+-form zeolites was evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia. 2.3 Catalytic testing The catalytic reactions were conducted in continuous mode, using a stainless-steel plug flow reactor (0.45 cm ID, L = 13.6 cm). Prior to reaction, the catalyst (100 mg zeolite in protonic form, 150–250 μm particle size, mixed with quartz) was activated at 550 °C for 8 h (heating rate of 5 °C min-1) in an air flow. The reactor was then cooled to reaction conditions under a nitrogen flow (30 mL min-1). In a typical run, a feed consisting of CH3SH/nitrogen = 5/95 (mol/mol) was introduced into the reactor with a flow rate of 10 mL min-1 (WHSV = 0.64 gCH3SH gcat -1 h-1). The complete reactor effluent was analyzed online by gas chromatography, using two apparatus/columns/detectors. The hydrocarbons were analyzed on a Varian 3900, CP-WAX-57-CB (25 m x 0.32 mm x 0.20 μm), FID, while the S-containing compounds were analyzed on a Shimadzu GC 2014, Supel-Q Plot (30 m x 0.32 mm x 0.15 μm), FPD. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction patterns reported in Fig. S1 (Supplementary Material) confirmed that the samples have the expected structure [21]. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms (Fig. S2), and the textural properties of zeolites (Table S1), are well characteristic of each topology. The NH3-TPD profiles consist in two peaks representing respectively the ammonia desorbed from weak and strong acid sites (Fig. S3). The amounts of acid sites are given in Table S1. 3.2 Catalytic conversion of methyl mercaptan over zeolites with diverse topology At temperatures lower than 400 °C, over all zeolites, the methyl mercaptan was mostly converted into dimethyl sulfide (DMS) and H2S (Figs. S4 and S5) with conversions ranging from 50% to 60%. At 400 °C, DMS was still the main product, but some quantities of C1-C3 hydrocarbons were also produced, notably in the presence of H-MCM-22 and H-SSZ-13. The most relevant results were obtained at 450 °C. At this temperature, the conversions of methyl mercaptan was about 56% for H-ZSM-5, H-Y and H-MCM-22, 63% for H-β and 72% for H-MOR and H-SSZ-13. These values did not vary significantly between 20 and 240 min on stream. In contrast to the previous studies carried out in the presence of zeolites [18,19], in which the aromatic hydrocarbons, dimethyl sulfide and H2S were not given, we considered all the products formed during the conversion of methyl mercaptan. Thus, beside DMS, significant quantities of saturated and unsaturated light hydrocarbons (C1-C3) and C6-C11 aromatics were formed (Fig. 1 ). For each zeolite, the ratio between the products (measured by GC between 20 and 240 min on stream) was quasi-constant during the catalytic test. The FID chromatograms plotted in Fig. 1 clearly show that the nature of the products generated as well as their proportion were strongly dependent on the zeolite used. We distinguish two families of hydrocarbons: aliphatic C1-C3 (methane, ethylene, ethane, propylene, propane) and aromatic (toluene, xylenes, trimethylbenzenes, tetramethylbenzenes and pentamethylbenzenes). Only traces of C4+ aliphatics and benzene were observed in some catalytic tests. The largest quantities of C1-C3 hydrocarbons, notably ethylene, were produced on the H-SSZ-13 and H-MOR zeolites (Fig. 2 ). In contrast, only small amount of low olefins were produced over H-ZSM-5 and H-MCM-22. In the presence of H-β and H-Y, the major aliphatic hydrocarbon was the methane. Significant quantity of aromatic hydrocarbons, like methyl- and poly-methylbenzenes, were obtained in the presence of H-ZSM-5, H-MOR and H-β zeolites (Fig. 3 ). The chromatograms presented in Fig. 4 (FPD detector) show that at 450 °C the two sulfur compounds obtained were hydrogen sulfide and DMS. In order to explain the formation of different classes of hydrocarbons, we will assume that the mechanism of transformation of methyl mercaptan into hydrocarbons is similar to that proposed for the conversion of methanol into hydrocarbons (MTH). For this process, there is a general consensus that lower olefins like ethylene and propylene are the result of a so-called “Hydrocarbon Pool” (HP) mechanism [22,23]. According to this mechanism, the aromatic species trapped in the pores/cages of the zeolites undergo successive stages of methylation by methanol and eliminate the light alkenes. In Scheme 1 we have adapted this mechanism to the conversion of methyl mercaptan. The primary hydrocarbons, notably propylene, can be easily involved in further acid-catalyzed reactions, such as methylation and oligomerization, leading to the formation of C4, C5 and C6+ olefins (Olefins Carbon Pool). Aliphatic C6+ species are involved either in cracking processes (to form propylene) or in hydrogen transfer reactions (with light olefins) leading to the formation of saturated hydrocarbons (methane, ethane, propane), aromatics and coke. In the case of methanol, methylation and cracking of alkenes has been shown to be an important route to the formation of C3+ alkenes, while ethylene is formed primarily from aromatic intermediates [24,25]. The results obtained in our study with methyl mercaptan show that over all zeolites, and under all conditions, ethylene was formed in higher quantities compared to propylene. According to data in Figs. 1 and 2, the molar ratio between ethylene and propylene was ∼ 2 for H-MCM-22, 3 for H-SSZ-13, 8 for H-MOR, and more than 10 for H-Y and H-β. Based on these results, we can state that the conversion of methyl mercaptan occurs primarily through the “aromatic” pathway in Scheme 1. The topology of the catalyst is crucial in the formation of the active intermediates involved in the HP mechanism. For example, 3D zeolites allow the fast diffusion of methylbenzenes towards the product flow, avoiding the accumulation of the HP active species in the pores of the catalyst [26,27]. On the other hand, the catalysts with large cages and small pores prevent to a certain extent the diffusion of these species. A first consequence of such behavior concerns the ratio between the aliphatic hydrocarbons (notably light alkenes) and the aromatic hydrocarbons formed in reaction. In the case of zeolites H-SSZ-13 and H-MCM-22, which have large cages and small pores, the methyl aromatics formed in cages cannot escape, and thus their presence among the products is insignificant. In a manner similar to that observed for the MTH process, H-SSZ-13 zeolite (with CHA topology) displayed the highest selectivity in light olefins [27]. Note that the selective transformation of methyl mercaptan into ethylene on a CHA catalyst has been predicted by Baltrusaitis in a previous DFT study [28]. In contrast, over 3D H-β and H-ZSM-5 zeolite, many aromatics and only few olefins were produced. This product spectrum rich in aromatics agrees with previous reports on the methanol conversion over similar zeolites [27,29,30]. The only exception in our case is H-Y zeolite, for which the amount of aromatics produced is insignificant. This difference could be explained by considering the density of the acidic sites on the surface. It is known that a high density of acid sites favors hydrogen transfer reactions, which are responsible for the formation of aromatics. Thus, the quantities of aromatics produced on the zeolites H-ZSM-5 (acidity of 1.92 µmol NH3/m2), H-MOR (2.08 µmol NH3/m2) and H-β (1. 50 µmol NH3/m2) were larger than that obtained on the H-Y zeolite (0.52 µmol NH3/m2). As shown in Fig. 1, the nature of the aromatics depended on the pore size of the 3D zeolites. Thus, the size of the channel intersection of the H-ZSM-5 zeolite allows the formation of benzene-toluene-xylene-trimethylbenzenes, but does not allow the formation of more hindered compounds, such as tetra- and penta-methylbenzenes. On the other hand, in the presence of large-pore zeolites, such as H-MOR and H-β, tetramethylbenzenes and pentamethylbenzenes are the mainly formed aromatics. When the catalytic tests were carried out at 500 °C, the methyl mercaptan conversion was of 90–95% over H-Y, H-MOR, H-β and H-MCM-22, and 98% over H-ZSM-5 and H-SSZ-13. At this temperature, the hydrogen transfer reactions were strongly favored and thus the main products were methane and aromatics, as shown in Fig. 5 for H-ZSM-5 et H-SSZ-13 zeolites. It is important to highlight the high aromatization capacity of methyl mercaptan shown by H-ZSM-5. According to the GC-FPD analysis, at 500 °C, an additional sulfur molecule, namely carbon disulfide, was produced (Fig. 6 ). The greatest amount of carbon disulfide was obtained in the presence of the H-SSZ-13 zeolite (15–30 times more than other catalysts), with a molar ratio between methane and carbon disulfide (the only two products obtained at 500°) of 3/1. The overall reaction which could explain the formation of the products identified at 500 °C is as follows: 4CH3SH → 3CH4 + 2H2S + CS2. 3.3 Catalytic conversion of methyl mercaptan over H-SSZ-13 zeolites Considering the performances demonstrated by the H-SSZ-13 zeolite in terms of olefin selectivity, we performed further investigations on this catalyst. The methyl mercaptan conversion was carried out at 400 °C and at atmospheric pressure, doubling the catalyst quantity (200 mg in place of 100 mg). Fig. 7 shows a typical chromatogram of CH3SH decomposition products. The product mixture is dominated by light olefins, mainly ethylene and propylene. Propane was also produced in significant quantities, and small quantities of methane, ethane and C4+ were produced. H2S and DMS were the dominant S-containing compounds (Fig. 8 ). However, they are not in equivalent quantities, suggesting that a large quantity of H2S comes from methyl mercaptan transformed into olefins: (2 CH3SH → C2H4 + 2 H2S; 3 CH3SH → C3H6 + 3 H2S). Fig. 9 shows the evolution of the methyl mercaptan conversion and the product distribution versus time on stream. The reagent conversion varied between 80 and 84% during the first three hours on stream, and it slowly declined afterward. At the beginning of the catalytic run (i.e. 10 min on stream), DMS was the main product (83%). The amounts of DMS and H2S were almost equal (Fig. 10 ). At 60 min on stream, the main products were ethylene-propylene (56%), propane (15%) and DMS (20%). The highest amount of olefins was 65% at 2 h on stream, but it significantly decreased thereafter, to reach 45% at 6 h on stream. In contrast, the quantity of DMS regularly increased, to reach 55% at the end of the run. This evolution of the product composition could be due to the deactivation of the catalyst. In summary, the chemical transformation of the methyl mercaptan with time on stream can be divided in three stages: (i) induction, with DMS as main product, (ii) steady state, when the olefins were the major products, and (iii) deactivation stage. Such an evolution is similar to that described for the methanol conversion into hydrocarbons [31]. As shown in Scheme 1, in a first stage, the methyl mercaptan is converted into DMS (a thioether). Further, molecules containing C-C bonds, particularly aromatics, are formed. These molecules, trapped in the cages of the H-SSZ-13 zeolite, will start the “hydrocarbon pool” mechanism, which is at the origin of the production of light olefins. As in the case of methanol, H-SSZ-13 (with CHA topology) deactivates rapidly because of the poly-aromatic species formed and confined in its cages. After the tests, the catalyst was completely black, proving that it underwent deactivation. The physical properties of the spent catalyst were determined using the same methods applied for the fresh samples. Before characterization, after the reaction run, the reactor was flushed with nitrogen at 400 °C for 30 min, in order to desorb the volatile species confined in the catalyst. The textural properties were evaluated from the nitrogen physisorption isotherms (Fig. 11 ). Comparing to the fresh samples, the coked catalyst shows lower adsorption capabilities at low relative pressures. This proves a reduction in the volume of the micropores, as well as the surface areas (Table 1 ). The amount and the nature of the species built up and retained on the spent zeolite have been determined by TG-MS analysis (Fig. 12 ). The CO2 and SO2 MS signals come from the combustion of C- and S-containing species. The overall mass loss was 5.72%. It was mainly recorded at temperatures higher than 500 °C, which correspond to the oxidative decomposition of the hard coke, most likely confined in the catalyst cages. The CO2 MS signal between 500 and 650 °C suggests that the hard coke contains only carbonaceous species. TGA-MS profiles also reveal a small SO2 MS peak appeared between 450 and 550 °C, as well as a shoulder in the CO2 MS signal. This can be likely related to the combustion of heavy S containing molecules, e.g., polysulfides located in the catalyst matrix. After a catalytic run (6 hours on stream) the catalyst was regenerated for 6 h, at 550 °C (temperature rise of 5 °C/min, under an air flow of 30 mL/min). The regenerated catalyst exhibited catalytic properties (activity and product distribution) similar to those of the original catalyst (Figs. S6 and S7). 4 Conclusions We have investigated the conversion of the methyl mercaptan catalyzed by zeolites with different topology. Based on the experimental results, some comments can be made as conclusion. • All zeolites are able to catalyze the conversion of methyl mercaptan into DMS and H2S (at temperatures lower than 450 °C) and into hydrocarbons and H2S (at temperatures higher than 450 °C). • The crucial variables affecting the nature of the hydrocarbons obtained over different zeolites were their pore size/architecture. The 3D zeolites mainly produced methylbenzenes, while the catalysts with large cages and small pores mainly produced light aliphatic hydrocarbons. • In the presence of H-SSZ-13 zeolite, at 400 °C, the methyl mercaptan was selectively transformed into ethylene and propylene. This behavior is analogous to that previously described for the methanol conversion into hydrocarbons. • The experimental results suggest that the conversion of methyl mercaptan over examined zeolites occurred mainly through the “aromatic” pathway in the Hydrocarbon Pools mechanism. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of methyl mercaptan was examined over zeolites with MFI, FAU, BEA, MOR, CHA and MWW topology and Si/Al ratio between 10 and 19. At 450 °C, over all catalysts, the reagent has been primarily consumed into hydrocarbons and H2S. The crucial variables affecting the hydrocarbon distribution over zeolites were mainly their pore size/architecture and the amount of the acid sites. Over 3D H-ZSM-5, H-β and H-MOR zeolite, many aromatics and only few olefins were produced. In contrast, and analogous to methanol-to-hydrocarbons process, H-SSZ-13 and H-MCM-22 zeolite (containing cages and small pores) mainly produced C2-C3 olefins.
